contents.context:
South Korean households began applying for emergency disaster relief today.
Online applications for credit or debit card points began at 7AM today, through websites or mobile apps of respective credit cards.
Under the five-day rotation system those born in years ending with 1 or 6 could apply today, and those in years ending with 2 or 7 can apply tomorrow.
The payment will be given in the form of card points two days after application.
There are limits on where it can be spent on: you cannot spend it outside the district of your residency, can't be spent at department stores, large retailers, or entertainment venues like bars and clubs.
Offline applications will begin at community centers or banks affiliated with credit card companies starting next Monday.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean households begin applying for emergency disaster relief funds on Monday
Updated: 2020-05-11 17:09:03 KST

contents.context:
Medical teams around the world could soon be wearing protective suits made with a new material developed by a South Korean institute. Felt, the main fabric used to make isolation gowns is in short supply as much of it has been used to make face masks. To find a solution, New York called the Korea Dyeing and Finishing Technology Institute, or DYTECH for help.

"This new material is durable and long-lasting. Protective suits made of felt tear easily and can be used only once whereas this novel material can be washed and reused. Amid the shortage of products due to the pandemic, this could be a groundbreaking invention."

Going through pressure and penetration tests, the fabric is more water-resistant than any other product on site. The core technology is the coating, which stops blood or droplets from entering the suit.

Developing the new material and sending samples to the U.S. took less than a week.
As the virus has stopped people from holding face-to-face meetings, the deal to export some 500 thousand yards of fabric was made online.

"We already had the database of different suit restrictions by country. With the accumulated information we could make a fabric that met U.S. standards and have it tested with a simulation system."

Negotiations are ongoing over exporting some 10 million yards of the fabric to ten countries. That's enough fabric to make 5 million suits. In order to meet the tremendous number of orders, DYTECH is planning to work with a dozen local businesses to deliver the suits in time. The institute says the COVID-19 crisis has become an opportunity for the domestic fabric industry.

"The institute aims to boost Korea’s overall textile industry by working with local sewing businesses to make complete protective suits. This is expected to lead to profits over 250 million U.S dollars. Choi Jeong-yoon, Arirang News, Daegu."
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
New material for protective suits developed by S. Korea
Updated: 2020-05-11 17:08:31 KST

contents.context:
South Korea has seen its exports fall during the first 10 days of May due to the impact of COVID-19.
The Korea Customs Service said Monday that exports from May 1st to May 10th amounted to some 6.9 billion U.S. dollars, down over 46 percent from the same period last year.
Car exports plunged over 80 percent, while petroleum products shrank over 75 percent, and semiconductors were down over 17 percent.
By country, exports to China fell about 29 percent, while shipments to the U.S. and the EU fell by more than 50 percent.
Even after factoring in the fewer working days at the start of this month compared to last May, daily average exports were still down some 30 percent.
Imports were also down over 37 percent on-year during the same period, due mostly to fewer imports of semiconductors, crude oil and machinery.

"The global economy has weakened and this is difficult for the South Korean economy, which relies heavily on exports. It's vital to control the pandemic so that consumption and world trade volume can pick up."

Amid falling imports and exports, the Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy held a meeting on Monday to discuss post-COVID-19 strategies.
The ministry said it will strengthen South Korea's non face-to-face sectors, virus prevention system and bio-tech to create future growth engines.
It also shared how it has been putting in efforts to diversify supply channels of key materials, including those needed for making chips and displays.
Yoon Jung-min, Arirang News.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's exports in first 10 days of May fell 46.3% y/y
Updated: 2020-05-11 17:07:11 KST

contents.context:
Time now for an in-depth look at the market news on this Monday.
And for that, I'm joined on the line by Dr. Yang Jun-sok, professor of economics at the Catholic University of Korea.
Professor Yang, thank you for making time today.

Thank you.

Last week, the U.S. had its biggest-ever drop in employment, but stocks on Wall Street closed higher. Korean stocks closed lower today, but the Kospi briefly touched the 19-60 mark for the first time in two months. What's the story today in the Korean markets?

From today, the Korean central government is accepting applications for the coronavirus relief payments for individual households. Already, local governments have been making smaller payments like this, which it's said has helped local economies. Do you think the nationwide relief payments will have that effect?

In the coming days we'll have numbers from the Korea Development Institute, also the Bank of Korea reporting on the financial markets. What should we be watching this week?

Alright, Professor Yang.
Thanks so much for sharing your insights.
We appreciate it.
Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
In-depth: Global market wrap-up
Updated: 2020-05-11 13:29:34 KST

contents.context:
South Korea will teach students the country's virus prevention methods dubbed "K-Quarantine" as part of its standard education system.
The Ministry of Trade, Industry, and Energy said on Monday, that as South Korea has shifted to "distancing in daily life", it will add educational contents about virus prevention to its curriculum for elementary, middle and high school students.
It will also prepare for the post-COVID-19 era by introducing a "blended learning" system, a mixture of both online and offline learning.
The ministry will push to produce digital textbooks and establish an e-learning system.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to teach virus prevention measures to school students: Trade Ministry
Updated: 2020-05-11 10:10:17 KST

contents.context:
South Korea has seen its exports fall during the first 10 days of May due to the impact of COVID-19.
The Korea Customs Service said Monday that exports from May 1st to May 10th amounted to some 6.9 billion U.S. dollars, down over 46 percent from the same period last year.
Petroleum products were hit the hardest plunging over 75-percent, while wireless communication products dropped over 35, and semiconductors, down over 17-percent.
Exports to China fell about 29 percent, while shipments to the U.S. and the EU fell by more than 50 percent.
Factoring in fewer working days at the start of this month compared to last May, daily average exports were down some 30 percent.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea's exports during early 10 days of May fell 46.3%
Updated: 2020-05-11 10:08:53 KST

contents.context:
As the South Korean government pushes for a third supplementary budget to cushion the COVID-19-related economic fallout, official are warning the nation's government debt to GDP ratio could go as high as 46-and-a-half percent, three years ahead of the government's initial projection.
According to the finance ministry Sunday the country's debt would reach 671-billion U.S. dollars after applying over 19-and-a-half billion, that's the amount of the first and the second extra budgets combined.
A surge in the debt to GDP ratio would negatively affect South Korea's fiscal soundness, and the issue is likely to be brought up later this month during a meeting with officials from the ruling party, the government and the top office.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
S. Korea's debt to GDP may rise above 46% if gov't pursues 3rd supplementary budget
Updated: 2020-05-11 10:08:53 KST

contents.context:
Hyundai Motor will roll out its new EV automobile equipped with the E-GMP, or Electric-Global Modular Platform, as early as January 2021.
The main production line is expected to be South Korean automaker's Ulsan Plant the world's largest single auto plant with approximately 32-thousand personnel producing an average of 58-hundred cars a day.
The vehicle is an important part of Hyundai's plan to have 44 electrified models on sale by 2025.
Hyudai says the E-GMP will offer drivers "customizing features, allowing them to alter space and configuration more efficiently."

Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Hyundai Motor's new electric model to arrive as early as January 2021
Updated: 2020-05-11 05:52:55 KST

contents.context:
The Trump administration is looking to fire up development of semiconductor factories in the U.S as concerns swirl about the country's reliance on Asia due to the renewed tensions between the U.S. and China over COVID-19.
The Wall Street Journal reports that Intel is discussing with government officials about improving domestic sources for microelectronics related technology.
The Taiwanese chip producer T-S-M-C have reportedly been in talks with the U.S. Department of Commerce about building a factory in the U.S.
U.S. officials are also reportedly looking at enlarging Samsung Electronics plants in Texas to expand its contract-manufacturing operations although the company has yet to confirm the report.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Trump administration in talks with chipmakers to build semiconductor factories in U.S.: WSJ
Updated: 2020-05-11 05:52:55 KST

contents.context:
The latest research shows the economic impact of COVID-19 in South Korea will be relatively smaller than that of other countries.
Bloomberg Economics forecast South Korea's economic growth for the year 2020 to be minus Point-1 percent, which is 2.4 percentage points lower than its forecast ahead of the pandemic.
In a report released Sunday on 31 major countries worldwide, South Korea is listed to have seen the second lowest decrease next to Hong Kong.
Korea also has the third-highest growth rate after China and Indonesia.
The IMF also forecast the country's growth rate to be the fourth highest amongst G20 nations.
The latest analysis has been attributed to the South Korean government's swift and effective countermeasures against the pandemic.
Reporter : mokyeon90@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Bloomberg Economics forecast S. Korea's growth rate in 2020 to be -0.1%
Updated: 2020-05-10 14:12:02 KST

contents.context:
Since the onset of the pandemic, Choi Hae-joung has been looking for easier ways to get meals on the table for her family.
One way she's found is ready-to-cook meal kits.
She says she orders them often these days because they offer a wide range of choices, they're convenient to cook, and because the virus has prompted her to stay away from crowded grocery stores.

"I order them online at least once or twice a week because we mostly eat at home as part of distancing in daily life, and the things I can make by myself at home are limited."

Many housebound consumers have made the same adjustment.
A survey of 1,000 people across the country was released in March by South Korean food giant CJ Cheil Jedang. According to the survey, about 83 percent of people are dining mostly at home, up roughly 24 percentage points on-year.
Of the respondents, 46 percent said the outbreak has them buying more ready-to-cook meal kits.

"As many people in South Korea have been refraining from dining out due to the outbreak, demand and the price of some staple food items have been on a volatile ride."

As of Friday, according to the Korea Agro-Fisheries & Food Trade Corporation, the price of 100 grams of pork was about 1 U.S. dollar and 84 cents, up roughly 14 percent from a year ago.
And the average price last month of a pack of 30 eggs was about 4 dollars and 36 cents, the highest it's been so far this year.

"Prices have gone up. The price of food items like pork, eggs and vegetables have risen because they're so commonly used in our daily meals in daily lives."

It's widely expected that cooking at home, like some other lifestyle changes, could last beyond COVID-19 when life returns to normal.
Eum Ji-young Arirang News.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
More S. Koreans eating at home due to COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-08 17:02:08 KST

contents.context:
South Korea is developing treatments for COVID-19 and they could be ready by the end of this year. It will also start clinical trials of vaccines sometime this year.
Hopefully following successful tests, a vaccine may be developed by next year.
This is according to a pan-governmental group set up to assist the development of treatments and vaccines for COVID-19.
They held a second meeting on Friday.
The group consists of top officials from the health, science, finance, SMEs and food and drug safety ministries, as well as the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and civilian experts.
An official from the group said that clinical trials are underway for 7 existing drugs to see if they can be used to treat COVID-19.
The official added that a positive outcome from some of the trials could lead to the development of a treatment "as early as the end of this year."
Three types of possible vaccines will also begin clinical tests before the end of this year, and hopefully, a vaccine will be available by the second half of next year.
To help speed up the process of developing a cure, the government has also revised regulations to allow the Red Cross to draw blood samples for research purposes.
Previously, only medical clinics had been allowed to draw samples.
Meanwhile, the government is also pushing to make the country's COVID-19 response measures dubbed the "K-Quarantine model" a global standard in tackling epidemics.
A policy council composed of government officials and experts was launched on Friday.
The council will work to come up with a detailed roadmap for the "K-Quarantine model", and propose it to the International Organization for Standardizations.
Kim Jae-hee, Arirang News.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
COVID-19 treatment could be ready as early as end of year: S. Korean gov't
Updated: 2020-05-08 17:02:08 KST
